signature_info.verified: A certificate chain could not be built to a trusted root authority.

x509.name: DigiCert Trusted Root G4
x509.serial number: 0E 9B 18 8E F9 D0 2D E7 EF DB 50 E2 08 40 18 5A

x509.name: DigiCert Trusted G4 RSA4096 SHA256 TimeStamping CA
DigiCert Timestamp 2024
x509.serial number: 0B AE 66 BC 5A BA 7F 95 87 C6 F9 E9 04 E3 33 04
x509.cert issuer: DigiCert Trusted G4 RSA4096 SHA256 TimeStamping CA

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert udp $HOME_NET any -> any 53 ( msg:"POLICY-OTHER TOR Project domain request"; flow:to_server; byte_test:1,!&,0xF8,2; content:"|0A|torproject",fast_pattern,nocase; service:dns; classtype:policy-violation; sid:43350; rev:3; )

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: APP-DETECT SSH server detected on non-standard port
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert tcp $EXTERNAL_NET !22 -> $HOME_NET any ( msg:"APP-DETECT SSH server detected on non-standard port"; flow:to_client,established; content:"SSH-",depth 4,nocase; pcre:"/^SSH-[12]\.\d+/ims"; reference:url,www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc4251.txt; classtype:protocol-command-decode; gid:1; sid:13586; rev:6; )

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious Encoded PowerShell Command Line
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects suspicious powershell process starts with base64 encoded commands (e.g. Emotet)
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Markus Neis, Jonhnathan Ribeiro, Daniil Yugoslavskiy, Anton Kutepov, oscd.community

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Hashes=SHA1=A72C41316307889E43FE8605A0DCA4A72E72A011,MD5=DCAADF7C9610B5EBEBDEDB1569EC4A9D,SHA256=D783BA6567FAF10FDFF2D0EA3864F6756862D6C733C7F4467283DA81AEDC3A80,IMPHASH=E09C4F82A1DA13A09F4FF2E625FEBA20; Description=Windows PowerShell; FileVersion=10.0.22621.2361 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WScript.exe" "C:\Users\Public\Libraries\resu.vbs" ; CommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" -exec bypass -w h -noP -nonI -enc  [TRUNCATED]; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\wscript.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: RDP Connection Allowed Via Netsh.EXE
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects usage of the netsh command to open and allow connections to port 3389 (RDP). As seen used by Sarwent Malware

match_context.values: @{CommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\netsh.exe" advfirewall firewall add rule "name=Remote Desktop" protocol=TCP localport=3389 action=allow dir=IN; Image=C:\Windows\system32\netsh.exe; EventID=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious PowerShell Encoded Command Patterns
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects PowerShell command line patterns in combincation with encoded commands that often appear in malware infection chains

match_context.values: @{Hashes=SHA1=A72C41316307889E43FE8605A0DCA4A72E72A011,MD5=DCAADF7C9610B5EBEBDEDB1569EC4A9D,SHA256=D783BA6567FAF10FDFF2D0EA3864F6756862D6C733C7F4467283DA81AEDC3A80,IMPHASH=E09C4F82A1DA13A09F4FF2E625FEBA20; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Description=Windows PowerShell; FileVersion=10.0.22621.2361 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WScript.exe" "C:\Users\Public\Libraries\resu.vbs" ; CommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" -exec bypass -w h -noP -nonI -enc  [TRUNCATED]; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\wscript.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious PowerShell Parameter Substring
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects suspicious PowerShell invocation with a parameter substring
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Daniel Bohannon (idea), Roberto Rodriguez (Fix)

match_context.values: @{Hashes=SHA1=A72C41316307889E43FE8605A0DCA4A72E72A011,MD5=DCAADF7C9610B5EBEBDEDB1569EC4A9D,SHA256=D783BA6567FAF10FDFF2D0EA3864F6756862D6C733C7F4467283DA81AEDC3A80,IMPHASH=E09C4F82A1DA13A09F4FF2E625FEBA20; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Description=Windows PowerShell; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WScript.exe" "C:\Users\Public\Libraries\resu.vbs" ; CommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" -exec bypass -w h -noP -nonI -enc  [TRUNCATED]; FileVersion=10.0.22621.2361 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\wscript.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious Binaries and Scripts in Public Folder
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of a file with a suspicious extension in the public folder, which could indicate potential malicious activity.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Windows Shell/Scripting Application File Write to Suspicious Folder
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects Windows shells and scripting applications that write files to suspicious folders

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious Manipulation Of Default Accounts Via Net.EXE
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects suspicious manipulations of default accounts such as 'administrator' and 'guest'. For example 'enable' or 'disable' accounts or change the password...etc

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=net.exe; Hashes=SHA1=76866DDE54EE3FA5BC8EFEFB9D44E6BF859973AA,MD5=BB1AE49B6B7C53499E94613761A6AC56,SHA256=AFBE51517092256504F797F6A5ABC02515A09D603E8C046AE31D7D7855568E91,IMPHASH=D45C37A5C97135204AD6E116C34946C3; Description=Net Command; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" -exec bypass -w h -noP -nonI -enc  [TRUNCATED]; CommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\net.exe" user Administrator /active:yes; FileVersion=10.0.22621.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\net.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Reg Add Suspicious Paths
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects when an adversary uses the reg.exe utility to add or modify new keys or subkeys

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Tor Client/Browser Execution
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the use of Tor or Tor-Browser to connect to onion routing networks

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Script Interpreter Execution From Suspicious Folder
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects a suspicious script execution in temporary folders or folders accessible by environment variables
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Hiding User Account Via SpecialAccounts Registry Key
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects modifications to the registry key "HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\SpecialAccounts\Userlist" where the value is set to "0" in order to hide user account from being listed on the logon screen.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potential Tampering With RDP Related Registry Keys Via Reg.EXE
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the execution of "reg.exe" for enabling/disabling the RDP service on the host by tampering with the 'CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server' values

match_context.values: @{CommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\reg.exe" add "HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server" /v fDenyTSConnections /t REG_DWORD /d 0 /f; Image=C:\Windows\system32\reg.exe; EventID=1}

@{CommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\reg.exe" ADD "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server\WinStations\RDP-Tcp" /v SecurityLayer /t REG_DWORD /d 0 /f; Image=C:\Windows\system32\reg.exe; EventID=1}

@{CommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\reg.exe" ADD "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Terminal Server\WinStations\RDP-Tcp" /v UserAuthentication /t REG_DWORD /d 0 /f; Image=C:\Windows\system32\reg.exe; EventID=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Root Certificate Installed - PowerShell
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Adversaries may install a root certificate on a compromised system to avoid warnings when connecting to adversary controlled web servers.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Change PowerShell Policies to an Insecure Level
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects changing the PowerShell script execution policy to a potentially insecure level using the "-ExecutionPolicy" flag.

match_context.values: @{Hashes=SHA1=A72C41316307889E43FE8605A0DCA4A72E72A011,MD5=DCAADF7C9610B5EBEBDEDB1569EC4A9D,SHA256=D783BA6567FAF10FDFF2D0EA3864F6756862D6C733C7F4467283DA81AEDC3A80,IMPHASH=E09C4F82A1DA13A09F4FF2E625FEBA20; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Description=Windows PowerShell; FileVersion=10.0.22621.2361 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WScript.exe" "C:\Users\Public\Libraries\resu.vbs" ; CommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" -exec bypass -w h -noP -nonI -enc  [TRUNCATED]; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\wscript.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potential Dropper Script Execution Via WScript/CScript
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects wscript/cscript executions of scripts located in user directories
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Margaritis Dimitrios (idea), Florian Roth (Nextron Systems), oscd.community, Nasreddine Bencherchali (Nextron Systems)

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Msiexec Quiet Installation
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Adversaries may abuse msiexec.exe to proxy execution of malicious payloads.
Msiexec.exe is the command-line utility for the Windows Installer and is thus commonly associated with executing installation packages (.msi)

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: PowerShell Core DLL Loaded By Non PowerShell Process
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects loading of essential DLLs used by PowerShell by non-PowerShell process.
Detects behavior similar to meterpreter's "load powershell" extension.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Tom Kern, oscd.community, Natalia Shornikova, Tim Shelton, Roberto Rodriguez (Cyb3rWard0g), OTR (Open Threat Research)

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft (R) Windows (R) Operating System; Hashes=SHA1=CB75ACC679A31148A5AAA97AB47EAD827713A5BB,MD5=77084D223E5EE73E9A892D02DE41EA92,SHA256=12011808F9B3A10CF774BEF58DECB41AA39275D3C7D3A35F90F210DA40FFEB03,IMPHASH=00000000000000000000000000000000; OriginalFileName=System.Management.Automation.dll; ImageLoaded=C:\Windows\assembly\NativeImages_v4.0.30319_64\System.Manaa57fc8cc#\ace3bea481888f9f1ead5c5a6936d779\System.Management.Automation.ni.dll; Description=System.Management.Automation; SignatureStatus=Unavailable; EventID=7; FileVersion=10.0.22621.2428; Signed=false; Image=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\executable.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious WSMAN Provider Image Loads
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects signs of potential use of the WSMAN provider from uncommon processes locally and remote execution.

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft (R) Windows (R) Operating System; Hashes=SHA1=925D006F3EC47A3155563B066B4F4DF8ABEA153A,MD5=66D41FDBD894A356A45DBEB366D73A82,SHA256=7E5C7A29C8C3EE1F27EF1B039ED7F3BC5D24A9F4042C8D32DD7E220DF9728632,IMPHASH=00000000000000000000000000000000; OriginalFileName=Microsoft.WSMan.Management.dll; ImageLoaded=C:\Windows\assembly\NativeImages_v4.0.30319_64\Microsoft.We0722664#\6eac6e432c8d4c572b2f7230c57ea8dc\Microsoft.WSMan.Management.ni.dll; Description= ; SignatureStatus=Unavailable; EventID=7; FileVersion=10.0.22621.1; Signed=false; Image=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\executable.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: New Firewall Rule Added Via Netsh.EXE
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the addition of a new rule to the Windows firewall via netsh

match_context.values: @{CommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\netsh.exe" advfirewall firewall add rule "name=Remote Desktop" protocol=TCP localport=3389 action=allow dir=IN; Image=C:\Windows\system32\netsh.exe; EventID=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Powershell LocalAccount Manipulation
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Adversaries may manipulate accounts to maintain access to victim systems.
Account manipulation may consist of any action that preserves adversary access to a compromised account, such as modifying credentials or permission groups

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious PowerShell Invocation From Script Engines
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects suspicious powershell invocations from interpreters or unusual programs

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Hashes=SHA1=A72C41316307889E43FE8605A0DCA4A72E72A011,MD5=DCAADF7C9610B5EBEBDEDB1569EC4A9D,SHA256=D783BA6567FAF10FDFF2D0EA3864F6756862D6C733C7F4467283DA81AEDC3A80,IMPHASH=E09C4F82A1DA13A09F4FF2E625FEBA20; Description=Windows PowerShell; FileVersion=10.0.22621.2361 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WScript.exe" "C:\Users\Public\Libraries\resu.vbs" ; CommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" -exec bypass -w h -noP -nonI -enc  [TRUNCATED]; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\wscript.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Hiding User Account Via SpecialAccounts Registry Key - CommandLine
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects changes to the registry key "HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\SpecialAccounts\Userlist" where the value is set to "0" in order to hide user account from being listed on the logon screen.

match_context.values: @{Hashes=SHA1=979F280B1226E064CC79020B25FB8C40D9FB0008,MD5=CDB58D0BCABE76AFC60428F364834463,SHA256=411AE446FE37B30C0727888C7FA5E88994A46DAFD41AA5B3B06C9E884549AFDE,IMPHASH=1085BD82B37A225F6D356012D2E69C3D; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=reg.exe; Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Description=Registry Console Tool; FileVersion=10.0.22621.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" -exec bypass -w h -noP -nonI -enc  [TRUNCATED]; CommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\reg.exe" add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\SpecialAccounts\UserList" /v Administrator /t REG_DWORD /d 0 /f; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\reg.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

@{CommandLine=C:\Windows\system32\reg.exe add HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\SpecialAccounts\UserList /v Administrator /t REG_DWORD /d 0 /f; Image=C:\Windows\system32\reg.exe; EventID=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: PSScriptPolicyTest Creation By Uncommon Process
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects the creation of the "PSScriptPolicyTest" PowerShell script by an uncommon process. This file is usually generated by Microsoft Powershell to test against Applocker.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: RDP Sensitive Settings Changed to Zero
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects tampering of RDP Terminal Service/Server sensitive settings.
Such as allowing unauthorized users access to a system via the 'fAllowUnsolicited' or enabling RDP via 'fDenyTSConnections', etc.
sigma_analysis_results.rule_author: Samir Bousseaden, David ANDRE, Roberto Rodriguez @Cyb3rWard0g, Nasreddine Bencherchali

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious Execution of Powershell with Base64
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Commandline to launch powershell with a base64 payload

match_context.values: @{Hashes=SHA1=A72C41316307889E43FE8605A0DCA4A72E72A011,MD5=DCAADF7C9610B5EBEBDEDB1569EC4A9D,SHA256=D783BA6567FAF10FDFF2D0EA3864F6756862D6C733C7F4467283DA81AEDC3A80,IMPHASH=E09C4F82A1DA13A09F4FF2E625FEBA20; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; Description=Windows PowerShell; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WScript.exe" "C:\Users\Public\Libraries\resu.vbs" ; CommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" -exec bypass -w h -noP -nonI -enc  [TRUNCATED]; FileVersion=10.0.22621.2361 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\wscript.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Access To Windows DPAPI Master Keys By Uncommon Applications
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Detects file access requests to the the Windows Data Protection API Master keys by an uncommon application.
This can be a sign of credential stealing. Example case would be usage of mimikatz "dpapi::masterkey" function

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Non Interactive PowerShell Process Spawned
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects non-interactive PowerShell activity by looking at the "powershell" process with a non-user GUI process such as "explorer.exe" as a parent.

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=PowerShell.EXE; Hashes=SHA1=A72C41316307889E43FE8605A0DCA4A72E72A011,MD5=DCAADF7C9610B5EBEBDEDB1569EC4A9D,SHA256=D783BA6567FAF10FDFF2D0EA3864F6756862D6C733C7F4467283DA81AEDC3A80,IMPHASH=E09C4F82A1DA13A09F4FF2E625FEBA20; Description=Windows PowerShell; EventID=1; ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WScript.exe" "C:\Users\Public\Libraries\resu.vbs" ; CommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" -exec bypass -w h -noP -nonI -enc  [TRUNCATED]; FileVersion=10.0.22621.2361 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\wscript.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Suspicious Get Local Groups Information - PowerShell
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Adversaries may attempt to find local system groups and permission settings.
The knowledge of local system permission groups can help adversaries determine which groups exist and which users belong to a particular group.
Adversaries may use this information to determine which users have elevated permissions, such as the users found within the local administrators group.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Local Accounts Discovery
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Local accounts, System Owner/User discovery using operating systems utilities

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae Windows\xae Operating System; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=net.exe; Hashes=SHA1=76866DDE54EE3FA5BC8EFEFB9D44E6BF859973AA,MD5=BB1AE49B6B7C53499E94613761A6AC56,SHA256=AFBE51517092256504F797F6A5ABC02515A09D603E8C046AE31D7D7855568E91,IMPHASH=D45C37A5C97135204AD6E116C34946C3; Description=Net Command; FileVersion=10.0.22621.1 (WinBuild.160101.0800); ParentCommandLine="C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe" -exec bypass -w h -noP -nonI -enc  [TRUNCATED]; CommandLine="C:\Windows\system32\net.exe" user Administrator 1qaz@WSX; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\System32\net.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.
